In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.   The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  is  in  the  preliminary  stages  of  reengaging  in 
economic policy advice and capacity development with the Government of the Republic of the 
Union of Myanmar. ADB adopted a three-phased process of reengagement with Myanmar in 
early 2012: phase I—preparation of initial economic and sector assessments as an extension of 
work  done  under  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  Program;  phase  II—conduct  of 
comprehensive sector assessments, capacity and institutional support, and project preparation; 
and  phase  III—resumption  of  lending  operations,  subject  to  satisfactory  progress  in  the 
country’s engagement with the international community and clearing of its arrears. ADB has 
completed phase I and is moving toward phase II by preparing for technical assistance (TA) 
operations focused on capacity building, institutional strengthening, and project preparation. The 
TA is fully aligned with and supports the Myanmar interim country partnership strategy, 2012—
2014.1In  particular,  it  supports  the  program  areas  of  (i)  building  human  resources  and 
institutional capacities in ADB core operational areas, and (ii) creating access and connectivity 
for rural livelihoods and infrastructure development. It also links into selected thematic and 
crosscutting areas of the Myanmar interim country partnership strategy. 
 
2.  The government has requested capacity development TA to support its economic reform 
agenda,  identify  viable  investment  projects,  and  initiate  preliminary  steps  to  prepare  pre-
feasibility studies for these projects. The TA is designed to support key sector ministries to 
outline a methodology for prioritizing selection of potential projects, identify feasible investment 
projects, and initiate the preparation of pre-feasibility analysis of pilot projects in these sectors to 
improve their capacities using practical tools and methodologies. The sectors included in the TA 
have been selected according to government priorities and the potential for ADB support, based 
on  preliminary  needs  assessments,  strategies,  and  road  maps.  ADB  sector  teams  had 
discussions with participating ministries from April to September 2012 to agree on the scope of 
the TA. The government concurs with the impact, outcome, outputs, and key activities as 
presented  in  the  design  and  monitoring  framework  in  Appendix  1.2 This  TA  complements 
another capacity development TA,  which provides advisors and training for government officials 
to identify sector needs and improve policies and institutional development in key ministries.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The government has instituted wide-ranging reforms as part of the ongoing economic, 
social, and political transformation. Major initiatives include the unification of the exchange rate, 
a new investment law, monetary and financial sector reforms, and changes to the trade union 
law.  The  government  has  also  initiated  the  process  to  identify  and  address  policy  and 
institutional issues at the sector level, with the support of ADB and other development partners. 
These reforms are essential in establishing a sound macroeconomic national policy framework 
and developing efficient institutions and policies. However, they are not sufficient to ensure the 
achievement of Myanmar’s development objectives. There is a need to simultaneously improve 
the capacities of government officials and ministries to develop methodologies and practical 
tools that allow them to identify and prepare viable investment projects. Macroeconomic and 
sector-specific reforms need to be implemented in parallel with viable investment projects that 
provide  tangible  benefits  to  the  population.  Projects  must  be  identified,  prepared,  and

implemented using efficient methodologies and mechanisms that respect environmental and 
social concerns, maximize economic benefits, and ensure financial sustainability. 
 
4.  Among the sectors that are expected to play a strategic role in Myanmar’s development, 
this TA will focus on transport, energy, agriculture and natural resources, and water supply and 
other municipal infrastructures and services. These sectors have been identified based on the 
expressed  priorities  of  the  government  and  the  results  of  the  preliminary  assessments, 
strategies, and road maps conducted by ADB staff 4. The government is making great efforts to 
improve performance in these areas and to address many issues confronting these sectors, 
including (i) improving organizational structures, (ii) clarifying institutional responsibilities among 
and within sector agencies, (iii) developing long-range strategic sector planning to prioritize 
public  investments,  (iv)  updating  policies  and  regulations,  and  (v)  improving  capacity  for 
performing  policy  and  regulatory  functions.  However,  all  these  reforms  will  have  to  be 
accompanied  by  specific  investment  projects  that  deliver  concrete  results.  After  years  of 
isolation,  sector  ministries  have  limited  experience  in  project  identification,  design, 
implementation, and evaluation. This has resulted in insufficient provision of infrastructure and 
low  levels  of  access  to  services.  There  is  an  urgent  need  to  assist  line  ministries  in  the 
identification  of  viable  projects  and  to  improve  their  capacities  for  the  preparation  of  pre-
feasibility studies for investment projects, which will use modern appraisal techniques, including 
economic and financial analyses, efficient procurement systems, environmental analysis, and 
other safeguard measures. Specific issues for each of the four priority sectors identified are 
described below. 
 
5.  Transport. The government has constructed a highway to link Yangon, Nay Pyi Taw, 
and Mandalay and has built many bridges in the country. However, Myanmar’s transport sector 
is underdeveloped for a country of its size, population, and potential. It is characterized by high 
transport costs and the absence of a sufficiently extensive lower level road network, restricting 
the access of much of the population to economic and social opportunities. The government is 
working to improve core sector issues, including (i) consolidating fragmented and overlapping 
institutional  structures  for  managing  development  of  the  sector;  (ii)  developing  an  overall 
transport sector strategy; (iii) improving capacity in sector agencies; and (iv) increasing the role 
of the private sector. A key issue that requires urgent support is the development of a more 
rigorous approach to select transport infrastructure investments and to prepare and implement 
road projects, using modern and efficient techniques. Capacity development support is also 
required to mitigate the potential adverse environmental and social impacts of the transport 
development through increased movement of people and goods, including the prevention of HIV. 
 
6.  Energy. Despite abundant energy resources and recent efforts by the government to 
develop energy resources, Myanmar has one of the lowest levels of energy consumption in 
Southeast Asia because of its low per capita income and inadequate energy infrastructure. The 
electrification ratio is low (26%) and system losses are high (27%). Persistent power supply 
shortages exist in Yangon and Mandalay; and existing power generation, transmission and 
distribution, and gas pipeline networks are inefficient and poorly maintained. The government 
intends to look at options to improve its fragmented institutional structure, which results in weak 
coordination and planning (e.g., there are no long-term energy supply and demand projections). 
However, other important sector issues include (i) difficulty in generation and transmission 
planning  and  operation  and  maintenance  caused  by  the  absence  of  electric  performance 
standards and a unified power grid code; (ii) weak experience in preparing feasible projects; and 
(iii) outmoded and inefficient legal safeguard requirements.

7.  Water  supply  and  other  municipal  infrastructure  and  services.  The  rate  of 
urbanization in Myanmar is relatively small compared to many other members of the Association 
of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), with urban development being dominated by Yangon and 
Mandalay. The government has recognized the need to develop (i) a coherent framework to 
harness private sector participation in urban development programs, projects, and activities; 
(ii) adequate  policy  and  strategic  guidance  at  the  central  and  local  levels;  and  (iii)  clear 
institutional  roles  and  responsibilities  for  planning,  management,  and  regulation.  However, 
chronic underinvestment in urban infrastructure, particularly in water supply and sanitation, has 
resulted in the lack of and/or poor quality of services, which can only improve if the policy and 
institutional reforms initiated by the government are accompanied by the identification and 
preparation of viable investment projects. 
 
8.  Agriculture and natural resources. The government has implemented reforms since 
2002 to increase private sector participation and productivity in the agriculture sector and has 
built several dams to manage water resources. However, the full potential of agriculture for 
contributing  to  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction  has  not  been  realized,  despite  its 
dominant role in Myanmar’s economy. Physical constraints (lack of access to markets and 
inputs, inadequate access to irrigation facilities, and substantial deficiency in the provision of 
electricity to rural areas) and policy-related factors (unattractive producer prices, high cost of 
farm inputs such as fertilizer, lack of access to credit, outmoded land tenure system, and poorly 
developed  research  and  extension  system)  have  obstructed  agricultural  development  in 
Myanmar. Core sector issues on which the government is starting to work, with support from 
ADB and other development partners, include (i) a clearer definition of the role, functions, and 
responsibilities of the departments within the Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation; (ii) better 
coordination and an improved water-based natural resources management; (iii) expansion of 
research and agriculture extension services; and (iv) increased level of access to rural finance. 
However, these reforms must be coupled with the identification and development of viable rural 
development projects that deliver concrete benefits to the rural population.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The  impact  will  be  the  successful  processing,  implementation,  and  monitoring  of 
investment projects in four sectors in line with stipulated standards. The outcome will be the 
improved  capacity  of  the  participating  ministries  to  identify  and  prepare  projects.  The 
consultants will work with government officials in the ministries to transfer knowledge and skills. 
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  Four outputs are envisaged for the TA with key activities as follows:  
 
11.  Output 1: Viable projects for the transport sector identified. Output 1 includes the 
following activities: (i) outlining a methodology for prioritizing and selecting potential transport 
projects,  (ii)  conducting  pre-feasibility  studies  for  two  pilot  road  transport  projects,  and 
(iii) conducting a pre-feasibility for a project to address increased HIV risks and vulnerability 
associated with the economic corridor development.

4 
 
 
12.  Output 2: Viable projects for the energy sector identified. Output 2 includes the 
following activities: (i) reviewing and formulating recommendations on power transmission and 
distribution regulations, performance standards, and grid and distribution codes; (ii) reviewing 
and formulating recommendations on specifications for distribution and power transformers, 
switchgear,  protective  relay  and  control  devices,  metering  equipment,  distribution  and 
transmission lines materials, etc.; (iii) outlining a methodology for prioritizing and selecting 
potential power sector projects; and (iv) conducting a pre-feasibility study for rehabilitation of 
power transmission and distribution networks. 
 
13.  Output 3: Viable projects for the water supply and other municipal infrastructure 
and  services  sector  identified.  Output  3  includes  the  following  activities:  (i)  outlining  a 
methodology for prioritizing and selecting potential urban sector projects; and (ii) conducting two 
pre-feasibility studies for the rehabilitation or expansion of urban infrastructure systems (water 
supply, waste water treatment, or solid waste management), including pro-poor community 
infrastructure. 
 
14.  Output 4: Viable projects for agriculture and natural resources identified. Output 4 
includes the following activities: (i) outlining a methodology for prioritizing and selecting potential 
rural development projects; and (ii) conducting two pre-feasibility studies, for community-based 
rural development projects in the Delta region and in the dry zone.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.765 million, of which $1.500 million will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The 
government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office 
accommodation, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. The government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit 
ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
16.  The Ministry of National Planning and Economic Development (MNPED) will be the 
executing agency. A subcommittee will be formed by the government, comprising senior officials 
from the participating ministries.5  The subcommittee will provide coordination for TA activities 
and be a forum for exchanging good lessons in capacity development for project identification, 
prioritization, and formulation across ministries. A TA focal point in each participating ministry 
will provide administrative support for the conduct of all activities. ADB will attend subcommittee 
meetings as an observer. 
 
17.  International and national consultants will be recruited by ADB in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). TA implementation 
is anticipated to require 39.5 person-months of international consultancy and 48.5 person-
months of national consultancy. The consultants will be recruited as individuals. The outline 
terms of reference are in Appendix 3. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance 
with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
                                                 
5 This will be the same subcommittee established under  the TA for Capacity Development and Institutional Support, 
which includes representatives from the ministries in charge of transport, energy, rural development, and urban 
development (footnote 3).

time). The duration of the TA will be from 1 January 2013 to 30 June 2014. Office equipment will 
be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to 
time). Upon TA completion, all equipment will be turned over to MNPED. The outputs of the TA 
will be disseminated through seminars, workshops, and publications. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Myanmar for Capacity Building Support for Project Identification, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Work 
 
1.  Individual consultants will be engaged to provide technical and advisory services to 
government  ministries,  identify  projects,  and  prepare  pre-feasibility  studies.  The  technical 
assistance  (TA)  will  require  39.5  person-months  of  international  consulting  services  and 
48.5 person-months of national consulting services. The consultants will be mainly based in Nay 
Pyi Taw and work inside the ministries.  
 
B.  Transport 
 
2.  Transport specialists (international, 3.5 person-months; national, 6.0 person-months). 
The international specialist will have overall responsibility for the pre-feasibility work on the two 
pilot transport projects. The international specialist will also be responsible for the transport 
engineering related activities to be undertaken in the work. The international specialist will have 
a strong background in transport policy development, preferably in developing countries. The 
international specialist will (i) act as team leader for the two pilot project pre-feasibility studies 
and coordinate with other team members to ensure timely delivery of all outputs; (ii) prepare all 
transport-related components of two pilot projects including engineering, costing, and design 
components; (iii) undertake an assessment of current asset management and maintenance 
programs  for  the  asset  management  project;  (iv)  undertake  initial  option  analysis,  route 
alignment, and project evaluation for the East–West Economic Corridor Project; (v) assess the 
capacity within respective ministries and undertake a needs assessment for asset management 
and project development; and (vi) prepare a training program to assist government officials in 
project evaluation, preparation, and implementation in line with Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
guidelines and requirements. The national specialist will assist in all tasks. 
 
3.  Transport economists (international, 1.0 person-month; national, 3.0 person-months). 
The international economist will be responsible for undertaking the initial economic and financial 
assessment of two pilot projects and for developing a related capacity development program on 
ADB  evaluations.  The  international  economist  will  have  a  strong  background  in  transport 
economics, preferably in developing countries. The international economist will (i) prepare the 
initial economic and financial assessment of the asset management pilot project; (ii) prepare the 
initial  economic  and  financial  assessment  of  the  East–West  Economic  Corridor  Project, 
including  options  analysis  comparisons  of  alternate  alignments  and  road  improvements; 
(iii) assess the capacity within respective ministries, particularly the Ministry of Construction, and 
undertake  a  needs  assessment  for  asset  management  and  project  development;  and 
(iv) develop a capacity development and training program for economic and financial evaluation 
following ADB guidelines and tool kits. The national economist will assist in all tasks. 
 
4.  Safeguard specialists (international, 1.5 person-months; national, 4.0 person-months). 
The international specialist will be responsible for the social, environmental, and resettlement 
safeguards for the two pilot projects, in line with ADB requirements. The international specialist 
will have a strong background in safeguards, preferably in developing countries and on ADB or 
World  Bank  projects.  The  international  specialist  will  (i)  prepare  the  initial  safeguards 
assessment  of  the  asset  management  pilot  project;  (ii)  prepare  the  initial  safeguards 
assessment  of  the  East–West  Economic  Corridor  Project;  (iii)  assess  the  capacity  within 
respective  ministries,  particularly  the  Ministry  of  Construction,  and  undertake  a  needs 
assessment of safeguard implementation and monitoring capacity; and (iv) develop a capacity 
development and training program for safeguards following ADB guidelines and tool kits. The 
national specialist will assist in the above tasks.

5.  Health specialist (international, 1.5 person-months). Based on recent studies on HIV in 
the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS), the specialist will develop a project proposal to address 
increased HIV risks and vulnerability associated with the economic corridor development in 
Myanmar. The suggested interventions must be evidence-based, cost-effective, and innovative 
based on the country and regional context; and complement and add value to existing HIV 
programs  being  implemented  in  Myanmar.  The  specialist  should  have  at  least  8 years  of 
working experience on health program design, and demonstrated writing and analytical skills 
and experience on project design and development, preferably with ADB. Tasks of the specialist 
will include but not be limited to: (i) review and assess in detail all existing HIV programs and 
implementation arrangements by government, nongovernment, and development partners; (ii) 
review  and  assess  current  models  or  approaches  in  the  provision  of  comprehensive  HIV 
prevention, treatment, care and support at cross-border areas; (iii) assess barriers to health 
service access, including ethnicity and gender factors; (iv) define priority target areas and 
population groups, and assess their exposure to risks and their needs for comprehensive HIV 
prevention, treatment, care and support; (v) conduct focus group discussions to assess needs, 
formulate  priorities;  (vi)  adapt  lessons  learned  from  other  similar  projects  and  studies; 
(vii) propose  possible  activities  and  policy  recommendations  to  ensure  accessibility  and 
availability of comprehensive HIV prevention, treatment, care and support to target populations; 
and (viii) produce a report for discussion with the government and development partners. 
 
6.  Health finance specialist (international, 1.0 person-month). The specialist should have 
at least 8 years of experience in health project finance. The specialist will lead the economic 
and financial analysis to reduce the incidence of HIV in the project areas. Work experience with 
ADB is preferred. Tasks of the specialist will include but not be limited to: (i) prepare cost 
estimates, financing plan, and economic and financial analyses; (ii) prepare the economic and 
descriptive context of the project components; (iii) review financial performance and projections 
(including recurrent costs) of the implementing agencies; (iv) recommend financial covenants 
based on the financial analysis; (v) recommend a summary funds flow mechanism based on the 
project design; (vi) assess financial, accounting, and internal control systems of the executing 
and implementing agencies, and the capabilities of maintaining such systems, and recommend 
measures to strengthen their financial performance and governance; (vii) examine appropriate 
disbursement mechanism and assist with the preparation of relevant sections of the draft project 
document; and (viii) describe auditing arrangements and financial covenants. 
 
C.  Energy 
 
7.  Power  grid  code  experts  (international,  1.0  person-month;  national,  1.5  person-
months).  The  international  expert  will  be  responsible  for  reviewing  and  recommending 
performance standards, grid code, and distribution code. The international expert will have a 
strong  background  in  performance  standards  and  grid  code  development,  preferably  in 
developing countries. The international expert must have a master’s degree and at least 15 
years international work experience in power sector. The international expert will (i) review the 
existing  performance  standards,  grid  code,  and  distribution  code;  (ii)  recommend  national 
performance standards, grid code, and distribution codes for Myanmar, taking into account 
those  of  neighboring  countries,  in  the  context  of  harmonization  with  the  Association  of 
Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN)  and  GMS;  and  (iii) organize  necessary  workshop  and 
training seminars. The national expert will assist in the above tasks. 
 
8.  Electric  standards  and  specification  experts  (international,  2.0  person-months; 
national, 2.0 person-months). The international expert will be responsible for reviewing and 
recommending standards and specifications for distribution transformers, power transformers,

switchgears, protective relay and control devices, metering equipment, distribution line materials, 
and transmission line materials, etc. The international expert will have a strong background in 
electric  standards  and  specifications,  preferably  in  developing  countries.  The  international 
expert must have a master’s degree and at least 15 years international work experience in 
electric equipment standardization. The international expert will (i) review existing standards and 
specifications for distribution transformers, power transformers, switchgears, protective relay 
and  control  devices,  metering  equipment,  distribution  line  materials,  and  transmission  line 
materials, etc.; (ii) recommend Myanmar national standards and specifications for distribution 
transformers, power transformers, switchgears, protective relay and control devices, metering 
equipment, distribution line materials, and transmission line materials, etc.; and compare them 
with those of neighboring countries in consultation with other concerned ministries; (iii) prepare 
the implementation plan, including cost estimation and the establishment of a testing institution; 
(iv) assist the Ministry of Electric Power in procuring basic urgent equipment within the budget; 
and (v) organize necessary workshop and training seminars. The national expert will assist in 
the above tasks. 
 
9.  Power  system  rehabilitation  experts  (international,  4.0  person-months;  national, 
10 person-months). The international expert will prepare a pre-feasibility study for rehabilitation 
and expansion of power transmission and distribution networks. The international expert will 
have  a  strong  background  in  power  transmission  and  distribution  networks,  preferably  in 
developing  countries.  The  international  expert  must  have  a  master’s  degree  and  at  least 
20 years  international  work  experience  in  the  power  sector.  The  international  expert  will 
(i) review the existing study and government plan; (ii) identify and prioritize rehabilitation and 
expansion  components  in  distribution  networks  in  Yangon,  Mandalay,  and  other  key  high 
demand cities in consultation with the Ministry of Electric Power; (iii) identify rehabilitation 
components in the transmission system; (iv) consult with other development partners; and 
(v) recommend an investment plan with priorities. The national expert will assist in the above 
tasks. 
  
D.   Urban Development 
 
10.  Urban management specialist (international, 4.0 person-months). The specialist will be 
the  team  leader  of  the  urban  development  team  and  will  be  a  senior  expert  for  urban 
development  and  infrastructure  (e.g.,  water  supply,  sanitation,  solid  waste  management, 
drainage, transport, and housing) with at least 15 years experience in related advisory projects 
with a senior level of government agencies. The specialist will have a demonstrated ability to 
manage interdisciplinary teams, cultural empathy, and sound organizational and reporting skills. 
Experience  in  Southeast  Asia  and  developing  countries  is  essential.  Tasks  include  the 
coordination and oversight of the pre-feasibility studies and related sector work, and preparation 
of the reports to the Ministry of Construction and ADB. The specialist will coordinate the urban 
team’s  dialogue  with  the  Ministry  of  Construction,  other  relevant  government  agencies, 
participating cities, local communities, and other relevant development partners.  
 
11.  Infrastructure  finance  specialist  (international,  3.0  person-months).  The  specialist 
should have at least a bachelor’s degree in finance, or a related discipline, and be a senior 
expert in urban infrastructure finance, with at least 10 years experience in related TA projects. 
The specialist will lead the economic and financial analysis of two pre-feasibility studies.  
 
12.  Social safeguards specialist (international, 2.0 person-months). The specialist should 
have at least a bachelor’s degree in environmental or social sciences, anthropology, sociology, 
or a related discipline, and be an expert in environmental and social safeguards (resettlement, 
indigenous peoples, gender) in urban infrastructure facilities (water, sanitation, solid waste,

12  Appendix 3 
 
drainage, and flood control, etc.), with at least 10 years experience in related TA projects. The 
specialist will assist the team with initial social safeguard examinations of the two pre-feasibility 
studies. 
 
13.  Water sector specialist (national, 4.0 person-months). The specialist should have at 
least a bachelor’s degree in environmental or social sciences, or a related field, with at least 10 
years experience in related TA projects. The specialist will have a thorough knowledge of the 
Myanmar water sector and assist the international specialists in the study of water companies, 
and their water and sanitation operations.  
 
14.  Civil  engineer  (national, 4.0 person-months). The engineer should have at least a 
bachelor’s degree in engineering, or a related field, with at least 10 years experience in related 
TA projects. The engineer will have a thorough knowledge of the Myanmar urban infrastructure 
field (water, sanitation, solid waste, drainage, and flood control, etc.) and assist the international 
specialists in the preparation of the pre-feasibility studies. 
 
E.  Agriculture and Natural Resources 
 
15.  Rural development specialist (international, 4.0 person-months). The specialist will 
assist in firming up the government development and investment priorities in the agriculture and 
natural resources sectors and assist in the concept preparation, project design, and initial 
project requirements for a rural development project, in consultation with relevant government 
agencies and development partners. The specialist will (i) engage in detailed consultations with 
relevant  officials  of  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Irrigation,  Ministry  of  Border  Affairs 
(Department of Rural Development), Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries, and other relevant 
government agencies, to identify the priorities envisaged by the government; (ii) in consultation 
with the government, prepare a set of criteria for selection of proposals for investment projects 
(including  grant  and  loan  funded);  (iii)  coordinate  with  development  partners  to  identify 
opportunities for synergies and to avoid replication; (iv) examine in detail high priority project 
possibilities, based on clearly identified criteria for project selection, including those that will be 
ready for immediate implementation to begin in 2013; (v) assist in the preparation of a Japan 
Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  (JFPR)  grant  proposal  for  a  community-based  livelihood 
improvement project in the uplands and dry zone areas in Myanmar that will (a) form part of the 
JFPR package for $10 million–$12 million (including the JFPR for $4 million for the delta region 
already under preparation; (b) identify effective modalities for financial flows at local level, 
including block grant and similar options for village development activities; and (c) recommend 
institutional and implementation mechanisms with the government and development partners; 
(vi) identify in collaboration with the government the most appropriate implementing agencies for 
this potential JFPR project; and (vii) assist in the preparation of a draft pre-feasibility study for a 
follow-on investment project in the dry zone and uplands. The specialist should have at least a 
master’s degree and at least 20 years experience in the agriculture, environment and/or water 
resources and prior experience in designing community-based rural development projects.  
 
16.  Rural  infrastructure  engineer  (international, 3.0 person-months). The engineer will 
assess,  identify,  and  help  prepare  the  rural  infrastructure  engineering  objectives  and 
implications  of  proposed  investments  under  the  JFPR  grant  and  the  follow-on  investment 
project(s). The engineer will (i) review the specifications for rural infrastructure works (rural 
access, communal irrigation schemes, post-harvest facilities, and potable water supply schemes) 
and prepare and agree on standard designs and specifications for use by townships and/or 
village tracts as appropriate; (ii) identify labor-based technology options; (iii) check, review, and 
evaluate detailed engineering plans, designs, drawings, detailed estimates, and programs of 
work submitted; (iv) establish mechanisms and standard costs to be used in determining the

Appendix 3  13 
 
work item unit costs that would be used to release funds for completed work; (v) organize and 
conduct training workshops for capacity building in the relevant field in accordance with the 
capacity building plan at the local level (district, township, village tract, or village); and (vi) assist 
the rural development specialist in any other tasks, including preparing various reports and 
other documents required by ADB and concerned government institutions. The engineer will be 
a qualified civil engineer with a bachelor’s degree and at least 15 years experience in designing 
and/or implementing rural infrastructure projects.  
 
17.  Procurement specialist (international, 2.0 person-months). The specialist will (i) set up 
the  procurement  system  to  handle  and  monitor  all  procurement  activities  following  ADB 
guidelines; (ii) assist in the preparation of detailed specifications and tender documents for the 
procurement  of  goods  and  services  including  shopping,  national  competitive  bidding,  and 
community services contracts and preparation of sample bid documents; (iii) establish a system 
for block grants and service contracts or seed capital disbursement to communities for services 
and investments; (iv) assist in identifying and recruiting prequalified institutions, nongovernment 
organizations, or private individuals to provide services for developing proposed subprojects into 
feasibility studies for consideration for project funding; and (v) provide on-the-job training in 
procurement and contract management to the procurement officer at national and provincial 
levels. The specialist will be a accredited procurement expert with at least 15 years experience 
in procurement-related activities for international organizations.  
 
18.  Rural development specialist (national, 4.0 person-months). The specialist will have at 
least a bachelor’s degree in agriculture, environmental, or social sciences, or a related field, with 
at least 10 years experience in related technical assistance projects. The specialist will have a 
thorough  knowledge  of  Myanmar’s  rural  development  sector  and  assist  the  international 
specialists in the design of the community-based rural development proposals.  
  
19.  Rural Infrastructure engineer (national, 4.0 person-months). The engineer will have at 
least a bachelor’s degree in engineering, or a related field, with at least 10 years experience in 
related  TA  projects.  The  engineer  will  have  a  thorough  knowledge  of  Myanmar’s  rural 
infrastructure  field  (rural  access,  communal  irrigation  schemes,  post-harvest  facilities,  and 
potable water supply schemes) and assist the international specialists in the preparation of the 
pre-feasibility studies.  
 
F.  Other Short-Term Consultants  
 
20.  Short-term advisors (international, 6.0 person-months; national, 6.0 person-months). 
The  advisors  will  be  recruited  depending  on  demand.  Specific  terms  of  reference  will  be 
prepared for each advisor and a request will have to be submitted by the ministry asking for 
support. The advisors will (i) conduct participatory consultation activities within the ministry to 
determine issues and areas requiring strategic and policy advice and action plans; (ii) work 
closely  with  the  ministries  in  developing  institutional  development  plans  identifying  support 
needed and action plans; (iii) prepare policy and strategy papers; (iv) conduct workshops, 
seminars, and conferences in their sectors; (v) conduct institutional development activities such 
as  (but  not  limited  to)  strategic  planning,  organizational  performance  assessment,  sector 
development planning, and action plan preparation; (vi) serve as resource persons (faculty) for 
in-country learning programs and work with the TA coordinator in the design, delivery, and 
evaluation  of  learning  programs;  (vii)  propose  new  policies,  systems,  and  procedures  for 
consideration by the ministry in line with institutional development objectives; (viii) monitor 
implementation of action plans; (ix) prepare process plans in consultation with the ministries; 
and (x) prepare periodic reports assessing the implementation progress of the ministries.
